title: The multiple LAYERS of childhood adversity
descriptions:
Here is a potential abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Multiple Layers of Childhood Adversity

This initiative seeks to establish a unified data infrastructure to investigate the life course impacts of multiple layers of childhood adversity on 2 million people across three generations. Childhood adversity is a critical determinant of health inequities that persist across generations. While current research focuses primarily on social adversity, this project recognizes that adversity operates at multiple, intersecting levels, including biological, health, social, neighborhood, and environmental factors. By integrating data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework, we will uncover the patterns, mechanisms, and dynamics of change underlying the long-lasting effects of childhood adversity. Our Real-World Policy Data Lab will simulate the impact of nationwide policies on childhood adversity, informing the development of targeted interventions to support vulnerable children and families. By redirecting the focus to the multiple layers of adversity, this project aims to identify critical targets for support, ultimately reducing health inequities and promoting a more equitable society.

Title: The Multiple LAYERS of Childhood Adversity

This initiative proposes to create a unified data infrastructure to investigate the complex, long-lasting effects of multiple layers of childhood adversity on 2 million people across three generations. By integrating interdisciplinary methods from data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework, our project will move beyond the current literature's primary focus on social adversity to examine the intersecting biological, health, neighbourhood, and environmental layers of adversity.

Our goals are threefold: to understand patterns of adversity, elucidate mechanisms of transgenerational transmission, and model the dynamics of change. To achieve these goals, we will establish a real-world policy data lab, integrating nationwide policies and simulations to inform evidence-based interventions. By redirecting the focus to the multiple layers of adversity, our research will identify critical targets for support, including children and families, and ultimately inform policies to mitigate the enduring impacts of childhood adversity on health and well-being.

Title: The Multiple LAYERS of Childhood Adversity

The Multiple LAYERS of Childhood Adversity initiative seeks to create a unified data infrastructure to investigate the complex, intergenerational effects of childhood adversity on 2 million individuals across three generations. By integrating insights from data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework, this project will move beyond the current literature's focus on social adversity to examine the biological, health, social, neighborhood, and environmental layers of adversity that intersect and perpetuate health inequalities established in childhood. Our goals are to understand patterns of adversity, uncover mechanisms that generate long-lasting effects, and simulate the dynamics of change. A real-world policy data lab will be integrated into the project, allowing us to test nationwide policies through simulations and identify targets for support, including children and families. By redirecting the focus to the multiple layers of adversity, this project aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of childhood adversity, ultimately informing policies that can mitigate its impact and promote health equity.
